awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The energetic costs of active sensory and communication signals: Integrating research and education through organismal, cellular, and molecular approaches
awd_abstract_narration:
Animals sense the environment using a combination of active and passive sensory systems in order to detect and respond to external stimuli. Passive sensory systems such as vision require little energy input from the animal because the carrier signal (light) comes from the sun. Active sensory and communication systems such as echolocation in bats are advantageous because they do not require external energy sources, but these animals must expend energy to produce the acoustic carrier signal. Managing these energetic demands and responding to energy shortfalls is essential for their survival and reproductive fitness. Running out of energy to generate the signal renders the sensory system "blind" and makes it impossible to find food, respond to threats from competitors, or attract mates.  The energetic demands of sensing and communicating are extreme in some species of electric fish - animals that generate and sense electric fields in the surrounding water to image their worlds and communicate in darkness.  This project aims to elucidate the organizing principles that allow animals to manage and exploit energetically expensive sensory and communication channels. The investigator will adapt knowledge, software, and technical approaches developed from this project's research activities to improve science literacy and education regionally, nationally, and internationally.  

This project will test the hypothesis that energetic demands are a major force shaping the operation and regulation of active sensing at the organismal, cellular, and molecular levels using the weakly electric fish, Eingenmannia viriscens, as a model system.  The research plan will study the electric organ discharge produced by the synchronized action potentials of specialized electric organ cells called electrocytes to (1) discover how hormones regulate electric signal intensity under normal conditions and in response to metabolic stress,  (2) discover how the cells that generate the electric signal increase their energy efficiency and respond to energy shortfalls, and (3) identify molecular adaptations in the electric organ cells' ion channels and ion pumps that optimize energy utilization. This project will integrate research and education through investigating the mechanisms that allow animals to use metabolically demanding sensory and communication signals. This project's educational component will achieve four educational goals that extend the investigator's track record of integrating research and teaching: (1) expanding and improving the investigator's outreach program, "The Electric Fish Roadshow", that promotes scientific literacy in settings ranging from grade-school classrooms to retirement communities [www.markhamlab.com/outreach.html].  (2) extending the scope and distribution of grade-school and middle-school lesson plans regionally and nationally, as well as international deployment of educational software for high-school and college neurobiology classes [www.EOTNprogram.org], (3) transforming the way student scientist-educators are trained in the investigator's laboratory and, (4) developing an undergraduate laboratory class in the investigator's department that involves students directly in high-level research activities related to the project's research goals.

por.por_cntn:
Animals must expend precious energy to gain information about their environment and communicate information to each other. This is especially true for more than 200 species of fish in Central and South America that generate weak electric signals to image their worlds and communicate in dark and opaque waters where vision is of little use. These electric signals are generated by specialized cells in an electric organ, known as electrocytes. The electrocytes generate electric signals using the same molecular mechanisms that nerve cells use to generate nerve signals in the brain and body. The resulting electric fields are detected by an array of electroreceptors on the skin and the fish analyze distortions of the electric field caused by nearby objects in the water to create high-resolution electrical images of their surroundings. Furthermore, sensing changes in the electric signals of nearby fish lets them use electricity as a social communication signal.

The electrosensory capability of these fish is a powerful adaptation that lets them actively gain information about their environments in complete darkness, even gaining information about the composition of objects in the water and locating prey hidden behind leaves and in mud – electricity penetrates where light cannot. These adaptations help to explain why electric fish are ubiquitous and abundant in the freshwaters of Central and South America. However, these electrosensory capabilities come at a very high cost – some electric fish species expend 20% to 30% of their daily energy budget just to generate electric signals. An important question is how these fish can maintain such an energetically costly sensory system, and how they might cope with situations where environmental disturbances reduce food ability and make less energy available to support electrical signaling.

Researchers at the University of Oklahoma (OU) addressed these questions through experiments that investigated the molecular mechanisms that allow electrocytes to be more efficient in generating the electric signals, examined how the electrocytes respond to changes in energy availability, and tested behavioral responses of the fish during periods of food scarcity. The discoveries produced by these experiments include the novel finding that leptin, a hormone that regulates appetite and energy expenditure even in humans, increases and decreases the amplitude of the fish’s electric sensory and communication signals in accordance with the animal’s energy reserves. This allows the fish to conserve energy when food is scarce, and resume normal signaling when food availability is high. The researchers also found that the electrocytes have two different mechanisms for sensing and responding to energy shortages. One pathway responds to the amount of energy that the individual electrocyte has available. This pathway depends on a novel type of ion channel (proteins that regulate the movement of electrical charge across the cell membrane) that was discovered as part of this project. A second energy-sensing pathway in the electrocyte responds to leptin levels that signal the energy available to the whole fish. Finally, the researchers found several novel and unexpected features of the electrocytes’ sodium-potassium pumps – the molecules that consume energy to produce the electrical forces that drive electric signals in the electrocytes. These adaptations in the pumps may allow the pumps to function faster or more efficiently.

This project also produced many important benefits outside of the research laboratory. The OU researchers expanded their outreach program, known as “The Electric Fish Roadshow”, which brings electric fish to schools, museums, and community groups. Participants can observe and take measurements of electric signals from the fish, and see how electric signals generated by their own nerves and muscles can be measured, highlighting that bioelectrical signaling is universal among animals, including humans. This program now reaches more than 300 participants per year. Assessments conducted by the OU research team showed that the Electric Fish Roadshow led to measurable gains in elementary students’ understanding of biological diversity, and increases in positive attitudes towards science – two key objectives of the outreach program. The OU researchers also updated and expanded their educational software that allows students to interactively investigate how certain molecules control the bioelectric signals of nerve cells.  This software is available to the public free of charge, and it is used by high schools and colleges worldwide with more than 12,000 downloads to date. This software became an even more important teaching tool during the Covid-19 pandemic when remote learning made hands-on laboratory exercises impossible. As another enduring development from this project, Biology students at OU can now take a laboratory class where they are actively involved in the kind of cutting-edge research with electric fish that this project produced.
